title: 109_s2375
content: The Act titled "Conquer Childhood Cancer Act of 2006" includes findings related to childhood cancer. The "Conquer Childhood Cancer Act of 2006" findings highlight the impact of cancer on children, with key points such as cancer being the leading cause of death in children, over 12,500 young people diagnosed annually, and the unknown causes of most childhood cancers. Childhood cancers mainly affect white blood cells, brain, bone, lymphatic system. Childhood cancers affect white blood cells, brain, bone, lymphatic system, muscles, kidneys, and nervous system. 80% of diagnosed children have cancer that has spread, and 90% are treated at Children's Oncology Group institutions in the US. The purpose of the following section is outlined. The Act aims to authorize funding for biomedical research programs, establish a national childhood cancer database, provide informational services to affected families, and support the development of an online information system on childhood cancers. The Act aims to establish a fellowship program in pediatric cancer research to support career development in pediatric oncologists. SEC. 4. PEDIATRIC CANCER RESEARCH AND AWARENESS. Amends the Public Health Service Act to include a section on pediatric cancer research and awareness. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a section on pediatric cancer research and awareness. The Director of NIH will establish special programs of research excellence in pediatric cancers, focusing on cause, prognosis, prevention, diagnosis, and treatment. Additionally, a grant mechanism will be developed for Research Fellowships in Pediatric Cancer to support clinical and translational research. The Director of NIH will award a grant for a national childhood cancer database, the Childhood Cancer Research Network (CCRN). The Secretary will award grants for public awareness of pediatric cancers and available treatments. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations totaling $20,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2011 is allocated for pediatric cancer research.
